name: Airen
description: By acreage the most widely planted white varietal in Spain, and the world as well.

name: Albalonga
description: German crossing known for producing rich if undistinguished dessert wines.

name: Albarino
description: The great white grape of Galicia in northeastern Spain, which shows many characteristics of the riesling, but with a bit of honeysuckle in the nose that?s more reminiscent of viognier.

name: Alvarinho
description: The Portuguese name for the immediately above from which vinho verde is created.

name: Alicante Bouschet
description: Nearly unique among red wine grapes, in that its juice is not white?solid pinkish, rather. Good CA blender.

name: Aligote
description: The second-tier grape of white burgundy, frequently dosed with creme de cassis to make kir.

name: Barbera
description: Aggressive high-acid Piemontese red wine varietal, more suited to red sauce or red meat than to simple sipping.

name: Blaufrankisch
description: Among the more interesting of the Austrian red varietals, solid body, good straightforward flavors, picks up earth tones well.

name: Brachetto
description: A red Muscat variety producing slightly fizzy low-alcohol dessert reds in Piemonte

name: Cabernet Franc
description: Very useful Bordeaux blender, softens the cabernet sauvignon in Medoc blends. Stands alone as a soft, luxuriant, chocolatey red in CA, food-friendly middleweight in France?s Anjou and Tourane.

name: Cabernet Sauvignon
description: The great red grape of the Medoc, makes pretty decent wine in California and Australia, as well.

name: Carignane/Carinena
description: Southern France & California for the first spelling, and Spain for the second, ripens rather well, full body.

name: Carminere
description: A substantial chunk of Chilean merlot has recently been shown to be this vanished sixth Bordeaux varietal.

name: Catawba
description: Good ?ol old fashioned Yankee grape. Nothing special.

name: Chambourcin
description: Hybrid varietal planted on the east coast USA; some pleasant aromatics, blends decently with pinot noir.

name: Chardonnay
description: Charter member of the champagne trio, where it absolutely shines as a stand-alone and a blender. Great white burgundies, not-so-great-but-still-yummy white burgundies, honking big California and Australian whites?

name: Chasselas/Gutedel
description: Light white with considerable terroir interest in Alsace and Switzerland under the former name, appears in Rheinhessen as the latter.

name: Chenin Blanc
description: Number one great white of the France?s Loire valley, long-living whites both dry and moelleux from Coteau de Layon and Vouvray, (also good value sparklers) and august dry white from Savennieres.

name: Cinsault
description: Rhone valley blending red. Member of the Chateauneuf-du-Pape crew.

name: Corvina
description: A good chunk of what goes into Valpolicella, Amarone, and Bardolino.

name: Counoise
description: Rhone valley blending red. Member of the Chateauneuf-du-Pape crew.

name: Dolcetto
description: Piemonte varietal producing luxuriously textured softish zaftig reds.

name: Dornfelder
description: Rheinpfalz reds of some character, earthy and showing a bit of spice.

name: Duriff
description: French minor-leaguer once thought to be same as CA?s Petite Syrah.

name: Dunkelfelder
description: German red, not invariably awful, but rarely of interest.

name: Ehrenfelser
description: Rheingau crossing, some interesting spicy white wines.

name: Folle blanche
description: French sort best used for distilling into firewater.

name: French colombard
description: Southern French, also used for brandy, widely planted for California jug-whites.

name: Gamay
description: (Un)fortunately banned in Burgundy (ca. 1486) by Duke Zorro the Vivisector, this cat beat it south to Beaujolais where he flourishes in the pretty weather. Can be made into real wine (Morgon, Moulin-a-Vent) as well as the dreaded Nouveau.

name: Gewurztraminer
description: German name, Italian origins (Termin); produces spicy (wurzig) aromatic whites in France?s Alsace region. Big wines?lots of flavor if occasionally simple.

name: Graciano
description: Spanish red varietal (small black grapes in Rioja and Navarra) producing high acid juice, blends nicely with tempranillo.

name: Grenache/Garnacha
description: Prolific easy-ripening red popular in southern Rhone and Spain.

name: Grenache Blanc
description: Cotes-du-Rhone white varietal. Easy ripeness and alcohol makes it popular among growers.

name: Gruner Veltliner
description: The Austrian national treasure?either light dry wines for guzzling in cafe, or profound fullbodied whites of a Burgundian cast. Characteristic green-pepper snap, nice citric aromas.

name: Huxelrebe
description: German crossing which ripens rather easily, and produces high-Pradikat wines of no particular distinction

name: Ives noir
description: We needed an item beginning with ?I? and discovered this rare bird hiding up in the Finger Lakes.

name: Jacquere
description: White grape making light crisp whites in Savoie.

name: Kerner
description: Slightly unique crossing of riesling with trollinger (that?s a white with a red?), spicy soft wines from the Pfalz.

name: Klevner
description: Occasionally called pinot blanc in Alsace, as is auxerrois?the two are sometimes rather casually blended.

name: Lemberger
description: Red German varietal, (Austria?s Blaufrankisch) some tasty wines, some merely quirky. Not so distinctively aromatic as the homophonous formaggio?

name: Malbec
description: Useful Bordeaux blender, stands alone in Cahors where it yields big reds of character, and in Argentina, where it is responsible for a number of interesting medium-priced wines.

name: Malmsey
description: Madiera?s name for the malvasia, producing rich sweet fortified wines. See ?Duke of Clarence??

name: Malvasia
description: A collection of white varietals of distant Greek origin, often blended in Italy and Spain to yield wines of interest.

name: Marechal Foch
description: French/American hybrid red. Planted in the eastern US, with no spectacular results.

name: Marsanne
description: White Rhone favorite, also grown in state of Victoria.

name: Melon de Bourgogne
description: The grape of Muscadet. Also much of what?s been called pinot blanc in Califonia.

name: Merlot
description: Source of the rare and precious Pomerol (and St. Emilion) in Bordeaux, along with a lot of nondescript soft reds from California and sometimes from Australia. Occasionally interesting as an Italian, from Tuscany, Friuli and elsewhere.

name: Molinara
description: Important member of the Valpolicella syndicate.

name: Montepulciano
description: The grape, not the village. Planted in the Abruzzo and the Marche regions of eastern Italia. Soft interesting reds. On the rise.

name: Mourvedre/mataro
description: Spanish, Cotes du Rhone and Provencial reds, frequently of great distinction, particularly when vines are old and yields are kept in check. Does nicely in California.

name: Muller-thurgau
description: German crossing of Riesling and Sylvaner, rarely distinguished.

name: Muscadelle
description: Sometimes seen in Sauternes blends, and in Gaillac.

name: Muscat
description: Grand Cru Alsace, bright spritzy Portuguese, grand and viscous Australian fortified desserts?

name: Muskateller
description: Dry, spicy, tropical-fruit-toned whites from Austria and Germany.

name: Nebbiolo
description: From Piemonte, the great red grape of Barolo and Barbaresco. Country-cousins are Gattinara, Ghemme, and Carema. Also called spanna?its home tag.

name: Negromaro
description: Southern Italian red?name means ?black and bitter.? Any questions?

name: Norton
description: Indigenous Virginia varietal, famous for the Monticello clarets in the 19th century, occasionally observed nowadays to produce real wine.

name: Odjaleshi
description: Red from (formerly Soviet) Georgia.

name: Ortega
description: German heavyweight of no real distinction.

name: Palomino
description: Spanish white, used to make dry sherries, and blended with PX to make the sweeter ones.

name: Parellada
description: Solid component of fizzy Cava in the Penedes region of Spain.

name: Pedro Ximenez
description: PX makes fabulously rich sweet wines in Montilla, and is used to enrich cream sherries

name: Petite Verdot
description: Bordeaux blender?if it wasn?t there, you?d miss it.

name: Petite Sirah
description: A blender essential for making Zinfandel into great wine. Occasionally interesting as a varietal, now thought to be a loose confederation of some half-dozen minor French types planted together as a field blend in Sonoma, mostly 100 years ago.

name: Pinot Auxerrois
description: Crisp Alsace whites, communicating interesting mineral tones.

name: Pinot Blanc
description: Light bodied gently spiced whites from Alsace, occasionally masquerades as Weissburgunder in Germany where it makes big fat wines.

name: Pinot Gris /Pinot Grigio
description: Produces whites both sublime and ridiculous in Alsace and Italy. Very fleshy and masculine in the former, light and dry in the latter. Planted in Oregon, where it produces some of the most interesting American whites, very much after the Alsace model. The Germans usually call it Grauburgunder?  They plant it in the south, in Baden, Franconia, the Pfalz.

name: Pinot Noir
description: The brilliant?if occasionally difficult?red grape of Burgundy. Does well in California, Oregon, Germany, occasionally in Victoria. A standout in Champagne.

name: Pinot Meunier
description: Thusly named because the plant looks like the miller (Le Meunier) has been dusting the leaves with flour. Germans call it Mullerrebe for the same reason. Important third in the trio of champagne varietals, where it?s a sponge for soaking up terroir.

name: Pinotage
description: South African crossing of cinsault and pinot noir. Interesting aromatic middleweight.

name: Primitivo
description: Southern Italian red genetically resonant with California?s zinfandel.

name: Quagliano
description: Makes pale red sparklers in Piemonte, and begins with ?q.?

name: Riesling
description: Great white grape of Germany, Austria, Alsace?very much a magnet for earth-tones, even with all of its glorious fruit?very popular once upon a time in Australia, and occasionally offering interesting wines in California.

name: Rondinella
description: See Corvina and Molinara.

name: Roter Veltliner
description: Wachau-region rarity from Austria. White wine, despite the red label.

name: Roussane
description: Cotes du Rhone white grape. Nice soft, oily texture, spring flowers in the nose.

name: Rulander
description: Name used in Germany for the grauburgunder (pinot gris) when it yields a dessert wine. Ruland was the guy who brought the grape to Germany from Burgundy.

name: Saint George
description: This is Greek wine, made by wine Greeks. Red of sometimes surprisingly substantial character.

name: Sangiovese/prugnolo
description: The great red grape of Tuscany?Chianta, Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, and (as sangioveto grosso) Brunello.

name: Sankt Laurent
description: Earthy Austrian red with spicy aromatics, often interesting.

name: Sauvignon blanc
description: Crisp dry whites on the Loire and from New Zealand, frequently overoaked pseudochards in California, surprisingly good in Austria?s Steiermark.

name: Saperavi
description: Another Georgian.

name: Scheurebe
description: 1916 crossing of Riesling and Sylvanner?German whites both dry and sweet with magnificent tropical fruit aromas, burgundian texture.

name: Schwarzriesling
description: Franconian name for Mullerrebe, which is German name for pinot meunier.

name: Scuppernong
description: Slightly obscene-sounding eastern American wild thing with fabulously proportioned vines and forgettable wines.

name: Semillon
description: Bordeaux white, prime mover of the great dessert wines of Sauternes. Good figgy-aromatic dry whites from Graves, quite interesting dry whites from Australia, where it also blends well with chardonnay.

name: Siegerrebe
description: This German white type will even ripen in England!

name: Syrah/Shiraz
description: Oh boy! The great long-living reds of the northern Cotes-du-Rhone, frequently impressive in California, interesting in Italy, Spain and Argentina?as Shiraz the benchmark for Australian red wine, where it shows a variety of styles, from soft and fruity to world-class profound. Also grown in South Africa.

name: Sylvaner
description: Slightly rustic mildly spicy white from Alsace and Germany.

name: Tempranillo
description: The great red grape of Spain, seen in many guises (Cencibel, Tinta del Pais, Tinto Fino, Tinto de Toro, et al) from the more delicate medium-bodied traditional Riojas to the rich, full bodied, more Bordeaux-like Ribera del Dueros to the powerfully ripe Toros.

name: Tocai Friulano
description: aka sauvignon vert, sometimes bottled in Chile as sauvignon blanc; some nice crisp whites.

name: Touriga Nacional
description: Important in creating the great Portuguese fortified wines of Oporto.

name: Trebbiano
description: Italian of many uses (ugni blanc in France) including the vin santo of Tuscany.

name: Ugni Blanc
description: Used to make Armagnac in Gascony, and to make wine by people who are too impatient to make Armagnac.

name: Vidal Blanc
description: American /French white hybrid of little virtue.

name: Viognier
description: Honeysuckle, orange-rind, mango-tinged aromatics. Silky textured white on the northern Cotes du Rhone, fat and succulent in California.

name: Viura
description: Good solid aromatic white Spaniard, also known as Macabeo in France and Catalunyia. Needs no oak to smell nice.

name: Welschriesling
description: Austrian varietal known for massively rich and spicy dessert wines, decent dry onces.

name: Xarello
description: Finds its way into fizz in Spain?s Penedes.

name: Yuga
description: Y? Because we love you.

name: Zinfandel
description: The great American success story. Spicy rich complex wines, particularly in Sonoma; hulking monolithic offerings from Amador and elsewhere in the Sierra Nevada range.

name: Zweigelt
description: Austrian red, the source of many easy-quaffers, but with a bit of what almost might be considered pinot noir character.

name: Red Blend
description: Proprietors blend of red wines - no more than 49% of any single grape

name: White Blend
description: Proprietors blend of red wines - no more than 49% of any single grape

name: Desert
description: Sweet Desert Wine

name: Rose/Blush
description: A typically blush or light red wine made from red grapes with skins removed early in the crush processing to produce a pink colored wine.
